newsitem.title: UK: OPTIONS - PIBOR vols stay high after rate cuts.
newsitem.headline: OPTIONS - PIBOR vols stay high after rate cuts.

text.p: Implied volatility of PIBOR options on MATIF remained at high levels after interest rate cuts in Germany and France, traders said.

"Most activity has been concentrated in the futures. There has been very little on the options -- the price is so wide that people don't know what it is worth," said Francois Magny, French desk trader at Nationsbank Europe.
"People are concentrating on re-hedging their positions at the moment and once things have settled down I guess they'll look in the options."
The Bank of France reduced its intervention rate to 3.35 percent from 3.55 percent on Thursday after the Bundesbank cut its repo rate to 3.00 percent from 3.30 percent.
By 1410 GMT September PIBOR futures were trading 31 basis points higher on the day at 96.07.
Magny said movement in the smile on PIBOR options was one significant development after the interest rate cuts.
Smiles are volatility plays which take advantage of differences in implied vols and are so-called because the vol curve traces out a smile.
"The smile is getting very acute. Puts are getting very well bid and the calls are getting much better offered," he said.
He said it was hard to predict how the market would change by the end of the day.
"Most guys got caught short volatility. They got hurt on their move and they will be looking to buy back in the near future," he said.
Players said options trading levels were low, making it difficult to establish the vol levels at which deals were going through.
Another trader at a French bank in Paris said implied volatility on September PIBOR options was at 42.0 percent and December at 32.0 percent -- both unchanged from Thursday closing levels.

"Vol should go down in theory," he said. But he added that with the underlying market having gained so much so quickly, predicting future moves was tricky so vols continued to be well bid. "It is not easy to sell volatility," he said.
The trader said volatility levels would remain stable at present levels over the next 24 hours.
He said September vol figures meant nothing so close to contract expiry and December levels were more worth watching.
"There will be transactions on longer maturities but everyone will look at this (December vols) to see what is happening."
